thread.title_full: Nikolaj Ehlers scores first NHL goal, Michael Hutchinson shines as Winnipeg Jets

author: torontosun.com
title: Nikolaj Ehlers scores first NHL goal, Michael Hutchinson shines as Winnipeg Jets
text:
NEW YORK – It would have been easy for the Winnipeg Jets to come unglued, throw their hands up in the air and concede that maybe this wasn't going to be their night.
After all, this is a hockey club that was playing on consecutive days for the second time on this four-game road trip on the East Coast and could have been emotionally spent following a disheartening defeat to the New York Islanders one day earlier.
But instead of folding up the proverbial tent against an Eastern Conference powerhouse and heading home with a .500 record, the Jets showed some resolve and found a way to rally.
Despite giving up the first goal on a three-on-one rush that was created by a bad turnover by Blake Wheeler at the offensive blue line, the Jets dug in and scored four unanswered goals to earn a 4-1 victory over the New York Rangers before a crowd of 18.006 at Madison Square Garden on Tuesday night.
As a result, the Jets return home for Friday's home opener at MTS Centre against the Calgary Flames with a record of 3-1.
“One of the things we worked on last year was being resilient,” said Jets goalie Michael Hutchinson, who made 40 saves and improved to 2-0 with another strong showing. “The games aren't always going to be smooth for the whole 60 minutes. You're going to have some adversity and we had some adversity right at the start, when they scored on a three-on-one.
“To answer right back is huge for our team, especially when it's one of our young guys getting his first goal. It lifts everyone up.”
A pretty goal by Mats Zuccarello, who finished off a tic-tac-toe play with linemates Derick Brassard and Rick Nash, put the Rangers up 1-0 at 6:45 of the first period.
But the Jets answer came 46 seconds later when rookie Nikolaj Ehlers blasted a slapper through a screen by Drew Stafford and past goalie Henrik Lundqvist for his first NHL goal.
“It gave us some energy to come back even harder,” said Ehlers.
The Jets played with far more pace than they did against the Islanders, but ran into some penalty trouble during the second period as they were shorthanded on five different occasions.
However, instead of seeing the floodgates open with a string of Rangers' power-play markers, the Jets turned the tables and got a shorthanded goal from Bryan Little to take the lead with 1:11 left in the second period.
“Sometimes you have a tendency to get off your game and start worrying about the refs. But at the end of the day, you can’t worry about that and you have to find a way to kill them off,” said Jets captain Andrew Ladd. “We did a good job. Our penalty kill stepped up with some big kills and that was a big part in our game.”
Not only did the Jets find a way to survive the second period, Little's goal gave them a big lift and it was the Rangers that spent too much time in the box in the third when they were trying to respond.
Little's second goal of the game provided some insurance and Mark Stuart closed out the scoring with an empty-netter.
“What we did today here we did last year consistently,” said Jets head coach Paul Maurice, whose club scored twice on the power play. “Every team needs to find its identity and needs to prove to itself that (they) can do it. Even if they've done it all of last year, it's a new year.
“It's really important mentally, for the psyche of our team, in terms of how we handle adversity.”
Finding a way to overcome that adversity was an important step, no doubt about it.
Going home with a winning record represents a strong start, especially when you consider the circumstances, but several areas need to be cleaned up – which is normal at this stage of the season.
“Honestly, it's nice to be 3-1 and when you look at it, it's a good road trip but I think we all know that we have better in this dressing room,” said Little. “Some parts of these games, it definitely wasn't pretty for us. There were a lot of times on this road trip that we got away from our game and got into penalty trouble. The feeling going back home is we can still get a lot better.”

Nikolaj Ehlers scores first NHL goal, Michael Hutchinson shines as Winnipeg Jets dump Rangers
By Ken Wiebe , Winnipeg Sun First posted: Tuesday, October 13, 2015 09:33 PM EDT | Updated: Tuesday, October 13, 2015 11:34 PM EDT
NEW YORK – During his first appearance on Broadway, Michael Hutchinson stole the show.
Making his second start of the young season, the Winnipeg Jets backup was up for the challenge as he made 40 saves and propelled his team to a 4-1 victory over the New York Rangers on Tuesday at Madison Square Garden.
The Jets wrapped up a four-game road trip with a 3-1 record and will face the Calgary Flames in their home opener on Friday night at MTS Centre.
With Jets head coach Paul Maurice giving Ondrej Pavelec a rest after he made 40 saves in a 4-2 loss to the New York Islanders, Hutchinson stepped in and was able to shine, improving to 2-0 and looking extremely confident in his first start at MSG.
But before the goalie controversy theorists get worked up, Hutchinson's start had more to do with the schedule itself as the Jets faced their second back-to-back situation of the season.
